model_input:
Your task is to choose a more helpful MEMORY based on the below criterion.

CRITERION:
Helpfulness - The MEMORY should contain information that is both useful and relevant, enabling the Child to respond in an appropriate context to the last utterance of the DIALOGUE CONTEXT. It is therefore important to ensure that the MEMORY contains only the information that is necessary for the response to be appropriate and effective.

The output format should be as follows:
Explanation: (a brief explanation)
Choice: (answer with "1", "2", or "tie")

Now choose the MEMORY that has better Helpfulness.

DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
Parent: You know, I always valued being a good listener. It's an important skill to have in life.
Child: Yeah, I think listening is really important too. I always feel heard when I talk to you.
Parent: That's great to hear. I think listening is especially important when people are going through a tough time. It can make a big difference to feel like someone is really hearing you.
Child: Did you feel like that when you were in detention? Like nobody was really listening to you?
Parent: Yeah, it was tough. I felt so alone and scared, and I didn't know if anyone would understand what I was going through. But eventually, I found someone who was willing to listen and it made all the difference.
Child: I'm glad you found someone to talk to. You know, I remember when we watched the sunrise together a few weeks ago. That was really special.
Parent: It was. I love being able to appreciate the beauty of nature. And you know, having my own place to live in the suburbs makes it even easier to do things like that.
Child: Yeah, your house is really nice. You've always been good at taking care of yourself.
Parent: Well, I've always valued my independence. Even as a kid, I wanted to do things on my own. That's why I decided to live on my own a few years ago.
Child: I can see why you would want to do that. You're just really good at being self-sufficient.
Parent: Thanks for saying that. But I still think one of the most important things I can do for others is listen. Whether it's to give advice, or just to let someone feel heard. 

MEMORY 1:
The parent values independence and self-sufficiency, which is why they decided to live on their own a few years ago. This decision was influenced by their desire to provide a safe and stable environment for the child. 
The parent's past experience of being in juvenile detention and going through a tough time when they got arrested led them to appreciate small moments and find hope even in difficult situations. This ultimately shaped their decision to live in a little house in the suburbs that they love.

MEMORY 2:
User Description:
Parent is an independent individual who values self-sufficiency and prefers to take care of themselves. They have made mistakes in the past but are focused on creating a safe environment for their child. Parent enjoys watching the sunrise and appreciates the small moments in life. They have their own place in the suburbs and cherish their independence.

Relationship Description:
The relationship between Parent and Child is one of love, support, and understanding. Child is always there to offer help and express sympathy towards Parent. They enjoy spending time together, watching the sunrise, and having breakfast in the backyard. Child forgives Parent's mistakes and offers support during tough times.

Event Description:
Parent recalls waking up early in juvenile detention and finding hope in the darkest situations. They remember the first time watching the sunrise with Child and appreciate the beauty of life even in difficult times. Child suggests watching the sunrise together again, showing their love and excitement for spending time with Parent. Parent is grateful for Child's support and appreciates their presence in their life.

YOUR OUTPUT:
prediction:
Explanation: MEMORY 2 provides a more comprehensive view of the relationship dynamics between the Parent and Child, highlighting the love, support, and understanding they share. It connects their past experiences and moments they have shared, such as watching the sunrise, which was mentioned in the DIALOGUE CONTEXT. This memory also emphasizes the Parent's focus on appreciating small moments and the Child's supportive role, making it more directly relevant and helpful in understanding the nuances of the conversation about listening and independence.

Choice: 2
